poll_list.title: Add WBTC-C as a new Vault Type - November 22, 2021

discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] New vault-type for WBTC with a higher LR

content.content: Overview DAI minted from WBTC been increasingly popular recently - the amount of DAI has tripled in the last month.  This development was the reason for yesterdays Mid-month Parameter Proposal of the MOMC and this Signal Request is about to follow up on an idea @Primoz brought up: providing a new WBTC-vault-type with a higher Liquidation Ratio. To summarize: if we encounter a large market downturn on WBTC vaults running with a higher Liquidation Ratio are less likely running into liquidations resulting in a loss for the protocol (and with that also the vault owner). More details on the state of WBTC can be found here. With the introduction of WBTC-B the situation might get even worse, as the capped line for WBTC-A might force users in the even riskier vault-type.  Shall we add a new WBTC-based vault type with a higher LR?  Pros  we could offer a WBTC-based vault with a lower Stability Fee - attracting more risk averse users if it gets adopted, we might be able to support more DAI from WBTC getting minted without increasing the fees (as the need to cool-down is lower)   Cons  we will likely see some WBTC-A vaults moving over to the new one, resulting in fewer revenue on them this is not just a configuration, but requires work in the Core Units      No Yes Abstain     0 voters      Next Steps The Poll will run until 2021-11-19T15:00:00Z, its outcome will result in an on-chain-poll assuming the outcome of the poll deems it necessary.
content.GPT-summary: The post is a signal request for a new WBTC-based vault type with a higher Liquidation Ratio. The author explains the reason for the proposal and the pros and cons of implementing it. A poll is included to gather feedback from the community. A 3rd party could give constructive criticism or ask questions about the proposal.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: For me it makes sense to introduce a third WBTC vault, given the recent significant increase in DAI generated from WBTC. Just want want to get you view on one quick thing. Here you say that “Maker also became the largest holder of WBTC, surpassing Aave and Compound. As much as this sounds promising, it means Maker carries the largest liquidity risk.” Introducing a third vault, and especially one that requires more WBTC in collateral, could most likely lead to Maker becoming an even larger holder of WBTC. How do you think this risk balances against the reduced risk of liquidation losses due to higher collateralisation on these vaults?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: I don’t think adding a third WBTC vault would lead to Maker becoming a significantly larger holder of WBTC. Pushing this to the extreme, if there was 20 types of WBTC vaults it wouldn’t lead to maker holding 20x more WBTC, it would just give more suitable options to people who plan to open a WBTC vault of some sort anyway. If Maker was concerned about holding too much WBTC, I think the right approach would still be to offer as much options as possible but to increase the stability fee across all WBTC vaults.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: milkmilk2:  If Maker was concerned about holding too much WBTC, I think the right approach would still be to offer as much options as possible but to increase the stability fee across all WBTC vaults.   Very good point!
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: I think there might be less user demand for a high liquidation ratio WBTC vault (eg WBTC-C with 170% liquidation ratio matching ETH-C), because WBTC vault users face some Bitgo custody risk with their pledged collateral. This incentivizes people to have relatively less overcollateralization (less money they would lose if Bitgo was hacked, etc). Maker also faces this custody risk, where if Bitgo lost funds vaults could become undercollateralized even if they started with a high collateral ratio. So one could argue that Maker gets relatively less benefits from high collateralization with WBTC versus ETH vaults. I’m in favor of trying this out, but don’t think we’ll see quite the same level of adoption as we have with ETH-C
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Thanks everybody, this Signal Request is now closed. I expect an onchain poll (probably in combination with the proposal for the initial configuration) happening on 2021-11-21T23:00:00Z
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: My apologies for forgetting to update this thread. This vault type is now WBTC-C and became part of the protocol on Nov. 29th when the execution of the executive spell:  vote.makerdao.com   Governance Portal The MakerDAO Governance Portal allows for anyone to view governance proposals, and also allows for MKR holders to vote.
